newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU energy ministers to tackle gas liberalisation.
newsitem.headline: EU energy ministers to tackle gas liberalisation.

text.p: European Union energy ministers will attempt next Tuesday to narrow their differences over partial liberalisation of the EU gas market, with a view to reaching a definitive accord by the end of the year.

The Dutch EU presidency hopes to broker a compromise at the Energy Council on three major obstacles to an EU directive on gas liberalisation -- the structure of market opening, the treatment of take-or-pay contracts and exemptions from competition rules for emerging markets and regions.
The presidency has not ventured to propose any definitive figures, leaving ministers to make the controversial decision on how far the member states will be obliged to open their markets.

A spokesman for EU Energy Commissioner Christos Papoutsis said on Friday that the Commission hoped ministers could reach an accord on principles on Tuesday but did not expect a firm deal on figures until after the forthcoming French and Irish general elections, possibly in July when Luxembourg takes over the EU presidency.

Papoutsis was not prepared to go ahead with a special session in June or July, unless ministers committed themselves next Tuesday to a "substantial opening" of the market, spokesman Costas Verros told reporters.
But he added that at the moment neither the Commission nor the member states were prepared to say what they interpreted "substantial opening" to mean.
Next Tuesday the Dutch will propose to ministers a two-level formula for progressively liberalising national markets.
The formula first defines "eligible customers", who will be allowed to negotiate contracts directly with the gas supplier of their chosing.
These include all power generators and large industrial customers who consume several million cubic metres of gas a year, though the figure has yet to be agreed.

As national fuel markets vary considerably -- with gas well- established in places like Britain or France but only just beginning to develop in Portugal and Greece -- there will also be wide variations in the share of the market which these eligible customers represent.

The Dutch are therefore suggesting that national governments should be able to modify their lists of eligible customers in order to comply with an obligatory EU-wide minimum threshold for liberalisation and an optional maximum ceiling.
Again it will be left to ministers to agree on the thresholds, which would both be raised in five years time.

Last December, EU energy ministers agreed to a formula for opening up the European electricity sector which obliges the member states to liberalise some 12 percent of their markets by 1999, rising to 33 percent by 2003.

While EU diplomats are predicting a possible agreement on a formula for liberalisation, they are less optimistic about ministers reaching a deal on the long term take-or-pay contracts with external suppliers in Russia, Algeria and Norway which dominate the EU's gas industry.

There is general agreement among member states that in cases where introducing competition into a domestic market causes a crisis for distributors locked into take-or-pay contracts, the national government should be able temporarily to limit newcomers' market access.
But there are deep divisions over how this will work in practice and who will be responsible for deciding whether exemptions from competition are justifiable.
"Commissioner Papoutsis thinks only the Commission will offer credibility and objectivity (in deciding) exemptions," Verros said.
This view is backed by Britain but Germany and France believe the decision should be left to their national authorities, a Dutch diplomat told Reuters.

She said the Dutch presidency would propose a compromise whereby derogations for existing take-or-pay contracts would be decided at national level while rulings on future contracts would be left to the Commission.
But she was pessimistic about the chances of an early deal.
Connected to this issue is the question of exemptions from competition rules for emerging markets, like Portugal and Greece, and isolated regions in other member states, such as Northern Ireland.

A British diplomat said there was general agreement that the two southern states should be allowed protection for 10 years but energy ministers still had to decide which regions from a list proposed by the Dutch would be allowed exemptions.
